text:
Hey all, I'm having serious doubts about continuing in my job and because this community is essentially what I want to do for a living, please allow me to seek your advice. Sorry if the following suffers from flaws of tone or content, but better out than in.

The other day I was writing some JSON validation boilerplate and I became quite stressed wondering if I picked the wrong career. And I've only been doing it for one year! I feel like I am wasting my time and not making use of the skills I have. Working as a software engineer doesn’t seem to be about “solving interesting problems”, despite what the recruitment ads say, nor is it about having the creative power to make your own work easier via automation.

Initially I got the impression they wanted “clever people” for the knowledge and design/engineering skill they can bring to the table, but actually the reality is that I don’t get to make use of 90% of what I’ve learned elsewhere, instead I just do the digital equivalent of manual labour.

I deliberately under-perform so that the code I write and the ideas I contribute are compatible with the mindsets of my coworkers. I've been surprised at the overwhelming lack of interest among them in the aspect of programming that you do yourself, i.e. architectural principles / design patterns.

Before I entered the industry I had the impression that this sort of thing was useful knowledge to have, and that people would just have ... discussions. But there barely is any discussion about our own craft except for specific named projects *other* people have come up with, like recommendations for Python webservers, testing frameworks, etc.

I'm also discouraged by the fear that if I display too much interest in that sort of thing then somebody will call me an Architecture Astronaut, and link to some article Joel Spolsky once wrote, and I won't know what to say.

Because so much of what I want to talk about is new stuff that hasn't been long established or even fully thought through yet, I take an 'improv' attitude towards ideas -- meaning, if something is absurd and half-baked then that is an *opportunity* for conversation and development. But people around me seem to take that as the *end* of a conversation -- interpreting it as a worked-through, actionable proposal, which has problem X and Y that are up to me, the proposer, to fix (instead of collaboratively fix due to the idea sounding promising.) After this happened enough times I just learned not to bother trying to contribute or communicate in that way. And it's not necessarily their fault; to me it boils down to two different reactions to absurd or half-baked ideas -- exploration or dismissal, each with valid contexts of use. I'm not that confident in my verbal communication skills, but I do manage fine with other topics, so I'm not sure that's the issue here.

So, if anybody else with basic programming and google skills could do what I do, then why should I take their job while constantly fantasising about actually making use of what I learned at uni and elsewhere?

Maybe I belong in research, but I don’t know how that works. I don’t know if you get to pick what you research, or if you have to sell it as something that will deliver concrete results after X years. (Thinking about the STEPS project here)

I already try to spend my free time doing my sort of informal research, but I'm surprised at how unenthusiastic I feel about it after I come home from work, having spent much of the day suppressing daydreams about the exact same stuff. If this was not the case, then I could tolerate my job, but the fact that it's stealing my energy from something I feel is far more important, is too much.

My first priority is finding out whether I could earn a living from doing the work I love, which seems pretty research-y. I know that there are people here in academia, and others in full-time employment, some of whom do work unrelated to "Future of Programming" and yet others who somehow do...? Can I seek your advice about what possibilities are open to me, or at least a starting point for finding out?

I can think of the following options:
1. Software isn't actually that bad, probably just the culture of the particular company you work in, try another place
2. Unfortunately many places are like this, but you should try companies that build programming tools / languages because they exist too
3. You really do sound like research would suit you better, so start by looking for programs related to "Software Creation Process", plain old PL research or even HCI
4. Other, obviously

Any thoughts?

> after I come home from work, having spent much of the day suppressing daydreams

Sadly, I know exactly what are you talking about

I was in similar situation before. There are jobs which require you to do more than just manual labor. It takes time to find a good one.

> Software isn't actually that bad, probably just the culture of the particular company you work in, try another place

Maybe the problems that they're trying to solve don't require this 'researcher' culture. If you find company that  solves more complicated problems, likely you will find more suitable culture.

> 2. Unfortunately many places are like this, but you should try companies that build programming tools / languages because they exist too

I got huge boost when I joined Erlyvideo that develops videostreaming server in Erlang. Maybe you shouldn't narrow your search for programming tools companies? Maybe just any job that tries to solve complex problems will be good?

> 3. You really do sound like research would suit you better, so start by looking for programs related to "Software Creation Process", plain old PL research or even HCI

I got an impression that it's better to dive into research after having some good experience in real world production jobs. Just to better understand the problems of today programming. Working alone on your projects might be not enough. Otherwise you may end up solving academic problems that don't really change things in production.

Thanks for the suggestion. I also read some HN comments on the article which was quite interesting.
<@UA14TGLTC> I think we often try to optimize the time needed to "make it work" without caring about qualitative attributes (performance, reliability, ...)

These are hard questions and I don't think that there's a simple answer to them. I'm still in university but will have to think about this in about a year too.
One thing I can add from personal experience is that working on the "future of programming" full time didn't work out for me. I took 6 months off and focused on my ideas. Afterwards, I was disappointed because I didn't make much progress that I could show others to prove to them that I hadn't wasted my time. You could say that it doesn't matter what others say, but I found that it does matter to me. Also, working on something for weeks and then realizing that it won't work out was really depressing for me.
My current plan is to get a job that's interesting but doesn't consume all my energy (maybe part time) and do researchy things as a hobby. 
I hope doing FoP stuff as a hobby will prevent me from feeling pressure to produce results as fast as possible. If it's just an additional thing apart from your regular contribution to society, you can do anything crazy, take as long as you like and stop whenever you like. This might be a good way to stay open-minded to all kinds of ideas and great visions.
Whether or not I'll actually do this and whether it will work for me - I don't know. I'll definitively follow the discussion closely, thanks for bringing it up!

<@UCQ4BBFQ9> Sorry to hear you’re having a hard time - these are tough issues. I remember feeling this way and it wasn’t fun. 

The good answer is that there are a lot of different jobs and careers - and if you don’t like any existing jobs, you can construct your own as well. That’s not to say it’s easy, but that there’s hope. 

My current approach is freelance to pay the bills plus research with a mentor to stay focused. 

From what you say, I’d consider switching to a less energy zapping job as a first resort. And there definitely are companies in this space that are hiring - pm me if you’re curious. Another option is to see if you can work more part time for your current or another job so as to give you more time to experiment. 

But whatever you do, don’t doubt yourself on this point: programming is batshit crazy and is begging for improvement. There’s a lot of work to be done here.
"Make it work, make it right, make it fast."  Ain't got no time for the second two!

<@UCQ4BBFQ9> Validation code is a sure path to questioning one's career choices.  Seen it time and again and experienced it most recently probably last week.  Sounds like your deeper concerns are connecting with colleagues and being engaged in the work.  Connection is important, else why bother?  Likewise, being digital manual labour isn't so bad if it's labour in service of a worthy end?  Fantasizing is a favorable sign, may just be that you aren't in an encouraging environment.  So outside of work, how have you tried to make fantasy into reality?  How did that feel?

Maybe we're "optimizing for delivery"?  There are parts of the write-up that resonated with me (failure at dependency management at scale). Yet other parts didn't (e.g. I sensed some conflation of 'high level' with 'poor performance').

> instead I just do the digital equivalent of manual labour
Yeah, I feel the same :point_up:
Where are you from <@UCQ4BBFQ9> ? What company are you working for?

> From what you say, I’d consider switching to a less energy zapping job as a first resort. And there definitely are companies in this space that are hiring - pm me if you’re curious.
Hey <@U5TCAFTD3>, I’m also trying to go to the freelance route to have more free time, any advices that you can share

Also the phrase '1% of the possible performance' - I don't think is necessarily bad. Many cars do run at a small percentage of the 'possible performance', for some value of performance, when you compare them to Formula 1, for instance. The overarching driving forces are mainly economic and based on the context of the problem being solved.
Cool, would love to help <@U85HCL7JP>. Maybe a call or google hangout sometime? Message me privately to schedule?
It’s hard to give general advice but happy to hear what you’re looking for

Congrats to <@U5TCAFTD3> for getting his paper accepted to the REBLS Workshop at SPLASH [<https://futureofcoding.org/papers/comprehensible-frp/>]

Anyone else going to be at SPLASH? Registration is pricey but it is one of the places where people working on the interests of this group congregate (including my LIVE workshop) <https://2018.splashcon.org/home>

Not only don't I care about performance, I think the obsession with performance is itself a big part of the problem with programming. Performance is the sort of crisp quantifiable puzzle nerds love to work on, unlike the messy subjective problems of making things simpler and easier.

<@UCQ4BBFQ9> sorry to hear about this struggle from you and others. My thoughts are closely aligned with <@UA14TGLTC>'s comment above - connection with people is important and also 'labour in service of a worthy end'. I don't have experience in academia, but I do think in the industry there's a wide range of technologies, cultures and environments. It's possible that even with the current state of programming, a software based job can be a positive experience. It might help to start by identifying your strong preferences, e.g. the technologies/languages, scope of problem, level of autonomy, etc. you'd want to keep you engaged. I feel the actual field (e.g. programming tools vs making apps) is less important. E.g. if you don't agree with the basic design choices and you don't have autonomy over them, a 'programming tool' may not be that much fun.
Congrats <@U5TCAFTD3>!
Also looks like <@UCDBW1H26> and <@UC21F8Q48> had their papers accepted in LIVE? (<https://2018.splashcon.org/track/live-2018-papers#event-overview>) Congratulations!
And <@UBKNXPBAB>!
Oh cool. Congrats from my side as well =)
I have a paper at OOPSLA

<@UCQ4BBFQ9> While getting out of there may be the right idea long-term, if you want to focus on improving your current situation, there’s a lot you can do with communication and precision. Your coworkers may be more reasonable than you realize.

Many people who shoot down proposals prematurely will respond better if you find common ground and make them want you to succeed, if you approach them 1-on-1 and get input early, etc. Those who jump to “this is overengineering” can be convinced if you can explain exactly what’s involved and exactly what future scenarios  each choice will help/fail in, especially if you have a track record of successful prediction; one of my clients reported this happening.

On overengineering: I recommend “What is Overengineering” by Max Kanat-Alexander.
